channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: Olympics opening ceremony director sacked for Holocaust joke
item.description: The decision to remove Kentaro Kobayashi comes a day before the opening show is due to be held.

item.title: Covid: China rejects WHO plan for second phase of virus origin probe
item.description: China says a proposal to audit labs shows "disrespect to common sense and arrogance towards science".

item.title: Pegasus: Princess Latifa and Princess Haya numbers 'among leaks'
item.description: Numbers used by Princesses Latifa and Haya are reportedly found in a database at the heart of the leaks.

item.title: 'It was hard to breathe': China flood terror as train carriage submerged
item.description: Passengers tell of their fear after a busy subway carriage was flooded in central Henan province.

item.title: Joe Biden says he's self-conscious as president
item.description: The president reflects on his first six months in the White House in a town hall hosted in Ohio.

item.title: Yuen Long attack: Hong Kong court gives seven jail time
item.description: The 2019 attack in Yuen Long was captured by victims and bystanders on phones and shocked the city.

item.title: I survived Norway's worst terror attack
item.description: Lisa Husby recalls hiding in fear as far-right extremist Anders Breivik went on a killing spree in 2011.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Black bear at softball arena still not caught out
item.description: There are no fans at the Azuma Stadium in Fukushima for the Olympic softball tournament, but US players are keeping their eyes out for a ticketless intruder.

item.title: John Coates: Australian Olympic boss in awkward 'mansplaining' row
item.description: In an awkward exchange, John Coates ordered politician Annastacia Palaszczuk to attend the Olympics.

item.title: Nord Stream 2: US and Germany reach deal on controversial Russian gas pipeline
item.description: The US says the agreement prevents Russia from using the pipeline as a political weapon over Europe.

item.title: Australia and NZ pull out of Rugby League World Cup
item.description: Australia and New Zealand pull out of the Rugby League World Cup because of "player welfare and safety concerns" related to the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: YouTube removes Bolsonaro videos for Covid misinformation
item.description: The tech giant says its decision was based on its content policies, not on ideology or politics.

item.title: Argentina introduces new ID cards for non-binary people
item.description: Under the new system, residents can select 'x' as their gender on passports and national ID cards.

item.title: Former informant 'White Boy Rick' sues FBI for $100m
item.description: The one-time teenage FBI informant says his work with the agency amounts to 'child abuse'

item.title: Pegasus spyware seller: Blame our customers not us for hacking
item.description: NSO Group tells BBC News: "The finger-pointing should be at the customer."

item.title: Covid: Where and why is the US vaccine rollout slowing down?
item.description: Vaccinations in the US are slowing as infections rise - we've looked at where and why this is happening.

item.title: Benin Bronzes: Nigeria dispute jeopardises return of artefacts
item.description: Several museums in Europe have talked of returning the looted artefacts - but where will they be housed in Nigeria?

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Travelling to an Olympic Games like no other
item.description: The BBC's Mariko Oi reflects on her personal experience of covering the Games during a global pandemic.

item.title: Soldier statue reignites Spanish row over fascism
item.description: Spain's legionnaires symbolised fascism, but Madrid may soon have a statue honouring them.

item.title: Sudan's Darfur conflict's latest surge in violence displaces thousands
item.description: "I have cried so much, my eyes can barely see," one mother tells the BBC after seeing her brother die.

item.title: China floods: Drone footage shows the scale of damage as clean up begins
item.description: As aerial pictures show the extent of destruction, our correspondent reports on the situation on the ground.

item.title: The 12-year-old becoming Tokyo's youngest Olympian
item.description: Hend Zaza from Syria reveals her inspiration for getting into table tennis at such a young age.

item.title: Halima Aden and Tommy Hilfiger: ‘It’s not just about diverse catwalks’
item.description: The world’s first hijab-wearing supermodel talks to fashion designer Tommy Hilfiger about why she quit the industry.

item.title: Dust devil almost takes out football players at match in Bolivia
item.description: The whirlwind, often mistaken for a tornado, came as a shock but appeared to cause no damage in Bolivia.

item.title: The jungle-trekking Covid vaccinators helping to protect remote Indian villages.
item.description: Latgam Singpu and his team use rope bridges, school buses and incentives to reach remote villages.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Sweden stun USA in women's football opener
item.description: Sweden's women's football team stun world champions the United States in their opening match at the Olympic Games in Tokyo.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Team GB women's football take the knee
item.description: Great Britain's women's football squad take the knee before their opening 2-0 win over Chile at Tokyo 2020.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Where might hosts Japan win medals?
item.description: The Japanese Olympic Committee has set a target of 30 golds in Tokyo, but in which sports might those medals be won?

item.title: 2032 Games: Brisbane confirmed as Olympic and Paralympic host
item.description: Brisbane is confirmed as the host of the 2032 Olympic and Paralympic Games after approval at an IOC meeting in Tokyo

item.title: From pretending to be a boy to going to the Games
item.description: Olympic boxing hopeful Caroline Dubois tells her incredible story of the journey to reach the pinnacle of her career.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Day-by-day guide to the key events, big stars and British medal hopes
item.description: Want to know what's happening when in Tokyo? Check out our comprehensive guide to all the action in Japan.
